title: Friday, 16th March, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
BE11:01am

Hey, hello, hi, welcome, etc.

OnYourRight Morning all
BE11:01am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing.

BE11:02am

PM's here, allegedly. You here PM?

chad_john Morning.
Soundbuy Morning
11:03 am
PM11:03am

Hi there -- thought I'd drop by

Blank canvas morning everyone. I see the Cheltenham redistribution of wealth continues apace

Thumbs up

Soundbuy He's behind you!

You'll have caught this bit of inter-paper sledging in the Mail this morning, I guess.

11:03 am
BE11:03am

BE11:04am

"Despite the fact that it is not a British-owned newspaper, it sells fewer copies than the Big Issue and its circulation is sustained by free copies given away in hotels (many of whose guests cannot speak English) the Mail ..."

BornCynic Morning
J L Morning

I mean, the Mail does do a lot of bulks .....

Gross Loydman Ooh, that's catty

red the ft's bias towards brexit is understandable given its target audience

Foreigners, coming over here and staying in our hotels

11:07 am

Wasn't the Mail in print down 11% last month, according to the ABCs?

red its often said those that will suffer the most from brexit will be those on the lowest pay, but equally many city folk could be on the wrong end of a hiding even if we get a soft brexit, never mind a hard one.
Paper Chase The guests cannot speak English? Whomever penned that piece can barely write it.

Oh, yeah it was. http://www.pressga...ouble-digit-drops/

undefined

Soundbuy FTSE 250 entrant Contour Global plummeting through the IPO pricing...........which is odd given the millions required by trackers.......bad day yesterday too......dropping the bid by 8p a throw.......
NEX Group PLC (NXG:LSE): Last: 887.00, up 216.5 (+32.29%), High: 930.00, Low: 855.00, Volume: 6.67m
Alchemy30 Morning, When did the rumours start on NXG, your London Report was out very promptly after market close adn it spiked prior to the BBG report.

Exchanges such as LSE and Deutsche Börse have been mooted, though both have personnel problems at the moment. MarketAxess or IHS Markit seem a more likely bet.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Instead, we get CME. But the feel is that this is the start of the process.

Miss Piggy Quadruple Option Expiry for S&P today, plus index shake-up, expect higher volumes today (US)
BornCynic @Pharma - you got it. They gave one to the French country manager of Pfizer for "services to the pharmaceutical industry"

And there's a lot of stuff around with regards a bidding war.

11:12 am

PM11:12am

Do share

BE11:12am

While CME has made an approach, we would expect other market intermediaries including LSE, Deutsche Boerse and ICE to consider an approach for NEX given the strategic value of its intermediary and post-trade assets to each of these businesses. Brokertec, EBS, Traiana, TriOptima, Reset and Information services each have strategic value given their established brands and accompanying wide customer networks.

11:12 am
BE11:13am

And it's partly the chance to chop out costs that appeals, so you can get some very big numbers here.

BE11:13am

NEX has disappointed investors in cost and margin terms since the broking disposal. The inclusion of the business within a larger exchange operator could provide the opportunity for NEX to invest more aggressively to take advantage of the regulatory driven growth potential across the post-trade business, NEX Optimisiation, in particular.

BE11:13am

While NEX markets and NEX Optimisation do have synergies, we would not rule out a bidder considering the break-up of NEX given the
potential for these assets to be more valuable individually to other parties. It is on this break-up basis that we set our potential acquisition price at over 1000p.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

At £10 you're looking at maybe £2.5bn, with Spencer getting 17% of that.

BE11:15am

You can see the appeal.

PM11:15am

Nice

11:15 am
PM11:15am

I'm dizzy with M&A

PM11:15am

· Europe M&A activity up 47% compared to YTD 2017 with $257.7 billion in deals

· Energy & Power M&A reaches $148.1 billion, up 21% compared to the previous year

· Global ECM hits $146.0 billion in proceeds, down 9% compared to 2017

· Asia (ex. Japan) Follow-Ons up 43% compared to the prior year with $29.6 billion in proceeds

· Global IG Corp Debt activity totals $751.4 billion, down 10% compared to a year ago

· Health Care DCM up 6% compared to YTD 2017 with $30.2 billion in debt raised

PM11:15am

GBKrona @DJ - Dinner Party Live

red esp if one is one the move a lot

the operating environment and its impact on transaction volumes, whilst sufficient for the business plan and five year profit guidance period that ends at 30 April 2021, do not support the step-up in Berkeley's production levels that these markets so badly need.

GBKrona @red - brill thanks
Miss Piggy @GBKrona: investing.com is a bust-out winner in the world of finance web sites.

GBKrona @Miss Piggy, @Pharma, @Red thanks - anyone know cheap (or free) way to get L2 info on UK/Euro stocks?
11:25 am
BE11:25am

That trading is on track is not a surprise, Berkeley Group is a master at its art, what policy makers and shareholders should note however is the challenges in increasing housing supply further. Whilst some view being a housebuilder as a licence to print money, it turns out that constructing homes is more complicated than building a printing press. We need more homes, but when even the master craftsmen are constrained we need Government policy to help not hinder and we hope that Oliver Letwin takes note.

VV75 Any comment on the Wethespoon CEO brexit rambling statement accompanying the figures?
PM11:26am

Yuck

BE11:26am

Hm. Or you can read it as a sign that there's a bit of fear behind their eyes.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

Which is how Robin Hardy at Shore takes things.

BE11:27am

There is often an attack on the tax and duty infrastructure impacting on the group’s markets but the tone of today’s statement is more aggressive than usual and could even be taken as indicating that the market climate is getting noticeably tougher, although that does not square with the stable guidance. So, there is no need to change forecasts for the near term or to alter the expectation that Berkeley is moving from making profits of £800-900m to making £500-600m. However, the valuation and many observer’s target prices seem to be based on the assumption that Berkeley might somehow be able to sustain those higher levels. The reaffirmation of the guidance and the clear indication that the board does not believe that the market climate will allow it to outperform that guidance is likely to prove a disappointment for the more bullish followers of the group. Our fair value is based on valuing Berkeley at a material premium to the rest of the sector (it is a very strong and innovative business after all) but even this only gets us to a fair value of 3350p.

GBKrona @BE - re:BKG - is there not a hidden profit warning for 2019, as trading statement states that 60% of profit forecast for FY18 and FY19 will be in the current year?
BE11:27am

So, at over 3900p the shares are looking fairly expensive and standing at the highest premium to fair value in the sector. When the shares were at 4200p after the interims we considered moving from our Hold recommendation to a more negative position but the sector then sold off and the valuation gap narrowed. It has widened again and the grounds for becoming more cautious on the recommendation are firming up again. We would, at the very least, still look to be taking profit here and, as with the other larger cap house builders, reducing weightings.

FATDAZ speaking of nominal margins had you seen speculation of 3% EU turnover tax for web giants and gig economy businesses would be tricky for Amazon with profit margin of 1.2%
red @GBKronadont trade enough to use L2 but maybe cmc?

The bit of the statement I enjoyed most was about how domestic buy-to-let investors, "who buy early in the cycle and provide security of cash flow to enable complex, capital intensive developments to be brought forward, are further impacted by additional transaction costs and the removal of interest deductibility’."

Groundhog Day @BE - regarding Spencer's attitude: have you ever heard anything regarding that? Ie has he got a reputation to not be a seller ever or would he rather be one to say "hey, 30% above the high seems like a deal to me". I appreciate it is your speculation and maybe you have not heard anything? Thank you
Miss Piggy @GBKrona: to take out market makers spread.

11:32 am

Okay, what else do we have?

GBKrona @Miss Piggy - brill, many thanks - very much appreciated
Groundhog Day thanks @BE
Miss Piggy you're welcome
BE11:33am

Typically slow Friday after a stupidly busy Thursday. I guess we can turn to sellside to keep us going.

BE11:33am

There's Fevertree, or Fever-Tree if you prefer.

11:34 am
Fevertree Drinks PLC (FEVR:LSE): Last: 2,929, up 27 (+0.93%), High: 3,019, Low: 2,922, Volume: 447.53k
BE11:34am

Premium Schweppes is a flop, says RBC.

BE11:34am

Our downgrade to Sector Perform in November was predicated on the risk of a slowdown in Fever-Tree's UK growth following the Schweppes relaunch and rollout of premium Schweppes 1783 at the end of last year. That said, the company's strong 2H17 UK organic revenue growth and the lack of progress in consumer awareness of Schweppes 1783 vs our survey in November, suggest that this risk hasn't materialized.

Patience @Miss Piggy - TD Waterhouse now called Interactive Investor - no Toronto Dominion connection.
alewis2005 does anyone *actually* talk about house prices at dinner parties?
chad_john no (yes)
11:35 am
BE11:36am

(Fairly sure they were doing 1783 at the British Library theatre bar a few days ago. It was okay. Tasted like tonic water.)

alewis2005 seems to me to be one of those things that's highly associated, but bares no resemblance to (my experience of) reality
BE11:36am

We estimate Fever-Tree's current UK volume share at 18% of the mixers category (around 40% value share) vs 33% for premium Gin, leaving a 15p.p gap to close. We assume Fever-Tree continues to close this gap with organic revenue growth progressively decelerating from 20% in FY18E to 10% in FY26E, implying 37% volume share (59% value) at the end of the period considered. Not easy, but plausible given Fever-Tree's strong execution in our opinion.

Miss Piggy @Patience: oh, long time since I looked at broker choice (I use HL and am ahppy). Thanks.
BE11:37am

So, buy up to £33.

alewis2005 *bears

Against an adjusted 2018 fully diluted EPS of 45.4p,

DJ Mitie?
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Berkeley - definitely whining. They've had the sunshine and now it is a little cloudy! What a shame!

BE11:40am

Oh, but you get America too! Because America, as we've established, have never even heard of tonic water. They drink their bathtub moonshine mixed with .... I dunno ...... Pepsi or something.

BE11:40am

We think the US is showing important similarities with where the UK was a few years ago (premiumisation and mixability, interest from distributors, shelf penetration, co-promotion with spirits players, own route-to-market, etc.) increasing our confidence in a progressive acceleration in the region. We expect organic revenue growth in the US at 30% in FY18, 35% in FY19 and 40% in FY20 (vs 30% previously).

One year into the Transformation Programme, Mitie is making progress and the expected cost savings have been increased by £5m. Cash generation has been impacted by higher costs of change, reduced reliance on invoice discounting and the normalisation of the balance sheet resulting in an expected £50m-70m increase in year-end net debt.

BE11:48am

11:48 am

BE11:48am

FY18 average daily net debt expected to be down £50m yoy (ie
c£286m vs £336m) but expect period-end net debt to be £50-70m higher than
last year (ie c£197-217m vs FY17’s £147m, above PHe FY18E of £168m). Cash
generation has been impacted by higher costs of change, reduced reliance on
invoice discounting and normalisation of the balance sheet. Mitie expects to
continue to comfortably operate within its banking covenants. PHe average net
debt/EBITDA c3.2x vs c2.0x y/end net debt/EBITDA (FY17: 1.4x).

BE11:49am

Forecast stepping back by 3-4% or so. Here's RBC.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Today’s statement further underlines the uphill struggle that the new management team is facing in terms of turning this business around. The stock has been amongst the weakest performers in the Business Services sector YTD and there is little in this update to alter the mood music. Whilst management is clearly trying to do the right things (taking out costs, simplifying systems and process, and putting some much needed investment back into the business), there appears to be limited tailwinds from its end markets and, in our view, this turnaround could be more protracted than originally thought. We remain cautious given the lack of clarity on the outlook.

Forester If anyone saw that documentation on ISS cleaning Premier Inns...that's what their up against!
BE11:49am

And Liberum.

Forester sorry documentary
BE11:50am

Management guides to 2-2.5% sales grow, vs. our old estimate of 4.4%. Management guides to operating profit that is in line with expectations, slightly down on the previous year. We had expected EBIT to increase from £70m to £80m, but now reduce EBIT to £78m. We reduce FD EPS by 3% to 13.3p. Management attributes this to higher investment.

There is no specific guidance on FY EBIT, but we reduce our estimate from £96.5m to £90.0m. We reduce FY FD EPS by 8% to 16.4p.

Management indicates that period end net debt is £50m to £70m higher than last year. Given £147m in FY 2017, we increase our FY 2018 net debt by £60m to £207m, vs. our previous estimate of also £147m. Cash has been impacted by higher costs of change. We expect average net debt to reduce from £335m to £286m.

Today’s warning is not entirely unexpected. However, we expect a negative reaction and we reduce our TP from 270p to 240p, based on a sum of the parts. The reduction is due to lower earnings and higher debt.

11:50 am
undefined

These PE multiples are well above five- and 10-year averages of 14.2x and 14.1x for Wetherspoon. Our 1275p share price target is based on a 19.0x PE for FY18E.

Mixed fortunes yesterday but the mares came good - hope you had both. So to the last day …
Nicky Henderson has a very strong hand today - 4 good win chances in the 1st, 3rd, 4th and 6th.
1:30. Half the field hails from Willie Mullins but I’ve gone with 2 Brits - APPLE’S SHAKIRA 7/4 win and REDICEAN 5/1 EW - they both have unbeaten records.
2:10. FLYING TIGER 12/1 EW won the Fred Winter here last year and likes the soft ground. A HARE BREATH 16/1 EW lightly raced and goes well fresh - ground a question mark. Bet365 paying up to 6 places.
2:50 the Albert Bartlett - stamina will be crucial here and SANTINI has that - 4/1 EW seems generous. POETIC RHYTHM last time out winner who should stay 12/1 EW
3:30. The big one - the Gold Cup & a very competitive renewal. I have 3 here - MIGHT BITE 4/1 would give Nicky Henderson the Triple if he wins. The northern raider DEFINITLY RED 11/1 but backed in from 16s antepost (would love to see him win!) and the charismatic EDWULF the Irish gold cup winner 12/1 EW. Sky & 365 paying to 6 places.
4:10 the Foxhunters Hunter chase. I have gone for a Paul Nicholls tricast! WONDERFUL CHARM 13/2, UNIONISTE 14/1 and VIRAK 14/1 all small each way bets. Up to 6 places available.
4:50. Conditional jockeys h’cap hurdle … DIESE DES BIEFFES 7/1 ridden by the excellent James Bowen. MELROSE BOY 16/1 second season hurdler who won here in November. Both each way. And a small each way flutter on the mare BRILLARE MOMENTO - a last time out winner - 22/1 for 6 places with 365.
5:30 the finale - three generously priced ones to finish on. DRESDEN 25/1 - in peak form on soft/heavy. GINO TRAIL front running good form on soft 25/1 and Northern raider FOREST BIHAN has decent form but ground not ideal 25/1. All small each way plays.

Have fun!
